Topological invariant for two-dimensional open systems

Jun-Hui Zheng ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ Walter Hofstetter Institut f√ºr Theoretische Physik, Goethe-Universit√§t, 60438 Frankfurt/Main, Germany.
Abstract

We study the topology of two-dimensional open systems in terms of the Green‚Äôs function. The Ishikawa-Matsuyama formula for the integer topological invariant is applied in open systems, which indicates the number difference of gapless edge bands arising from the poles and zeros of the Green‚Äôs function. Meanwhile, we define another topological invariant via the single-particle density matrix, which works for general gapped systems and is equivalent to the former for the case of weak coupling to an environment. We also discuss two applications. For time-reversal-invariant insulators, the Z2subscriptùëç2{Z}_{2} index can be expressed by the invariant of each spin subsystem. As a second application, we consider the proximity effect when an ordinary insulator is coupled to a topological insulator.

I Introduction

The study of the quantum Hall effect has led to the new classification paradigm of quantum phases based on topological properties‚ÄâThouless1982prl ; Wen1990prb ; Hasan2010rmp ; Qi2011rmp . The corresponding topological invariants have been constructed for various systems with interaction‚ÄâThouless1982prl ; Ishkawa1987npb ; Wang2010prl ; Gurarie2011prb ; Niu1985prb , with disorder‚ÄâNiu1985prb , and with time-reversal symmetry‚ÄâKane2005prl ; Sheng2006prl ; Lee2008prl . For the noninteracting case, the topological index is given by the integral of the Berry curvature determined by single-particle wave functions of the system‚ÄâThouless1982prl ; Wang2010prl . For the interacting case, it is more convenient to use the expression in terms of the single-particle Green‚Äôs function‚ÄâIshkawa1987npb instead of the many-body wave function‚ÄâNiu1985prb . In combination with (dynamical) mean field theory‚ÄâGeorges1996rmp , it is feasible to obtain the topological index by calculating multiple integrals of the interacting Green‚Äôs function‚ÄâWang2012epl . Meanwhile, two new developments have allowed us to simplify the calculation: (1) the topological Hamiltonian method, which captures topological properties of the original interacting Hamiltonian‚ÄâWang2012prx , and (2) the quasiparticle Berry curvature method, where the Berry curvature is determined by the quasiparticle states if these states have a long lifetime‚ÄâShindou2008prb .

However, all of these methods are valid only for closed quantum systems. A realistic system, inevitably, is coupled to an environment. Especially for the noninteracting case, the ground state of an open system is expected to be a reduced density matrix (a mixed state) rather than a pure state. An extension of the Berry phase to mixed states in one-dimensional systems Uhlmann1986 ; Nieuwenburg2014 and related observables (e.g., Thouless pumping) Linzner2016prb ; Bardyn2017 has been proposed. For two-dimensional (2D) systems, there are several different versions of topological invariants for a general density matrix‚ÄâDiehl2011np ; Rivas2013prb ; Bardyn2013njp ; Huang2014prl ; Budich2015prb ; Grusdt2017 , and only one of them corresponds to the U‚Äã(1)ùëà1U(1) holonomy‚ÄâBudich2015prb . To include interaction effects, like for closed systems, the best option is to express the topological invariant in terms of the Green‚Äôs function.

For a general system Aùê¥A immersed in an environment Eùê∏E, the effective partition function can be obtained by integrating out the degree of freedom of Eùê∏E. The resulting effective action retains the U‚Äã(1)ùëà1U(1) symmetry 111 The effective action is invariant under the U‚Äã(1)ùëà1U(1) transformation cA‚Üíei‚ÄãŒ∏‚ÄãcA‚Üísubscriptùëêùê¥superscriptùëíùëñùúÉsubscriptùëêùê¥c_{A}\rightarrow e^{i\theta}c_{A}, where cAsubscriptùëêùê¥c_{A} is the Grassmann field. For the case of weak coupling to the environment, the relaxation time of density fluctuations is supposed to be short, so that the total particle number of subsystem Aùê¥A is approximately conserved. On the other hand, in the thermodynamic limit, the fluctuations of the total particle number in system Aùê¥A are also suppressed;, thus, the U‚Äã(1)ùëà1U(1) symmetry, at a certain timescale, is obtained. . Accordingly, the first Chern number of the system Aùê¥A can be defined by the Ishikawa-Matsuyama formula,

Here, œÉùúé\sigma and œÉ‚Ä≤superscriptùúé‚Ä≤\sigma^{\prime} represent the internal degrees of freedom of Aùê¥A. The translational symmetry is assumed for both Aùê¥A and Eùê∏E. The index (1) is a well-defined topological invariant‚ÄâQi2008prb iff there are neither poles nor zeros for GA‚Äã(ùê§,i‚Äãœâ)subscriptùê∫ùê¥ùê§ùëñùúîG_{A}(\mathbf{k},i\omega) for all ùê§ùê§\mathbf{k} and imaginary frequency i‚Äãœâùëñùúîi\omega.

We develop both the topological Hamiltonian method and the Berry curvature method to evaluate Eq.‚Äâ(1). The topological Hamiltonian gives an effective single-particle description of the open system. On the other hand, the Berry curvature method shows that for an open system, besides the bands determined by the poles of the Green‚Äôs function (energy spectrum), the ‚Äúbands‚Äù œâ‚Äã(ùê§)ùúîùê§\omega(\mathbf{k}) from the zeros (denoted as blind bands here), i.e., det‚ÄãGA‚Äã(ùê§,œâ‚Äã(ùê§))=0detsubscriptùê∫ùê¥ùê§ùúîùê§0\text{det}G_{A}(\mathbf{k},\omega(\mathbf{k}))=0, appear and contribute to the topological properties. The value of ChAsubscriptChùê¥\text{Ch}_{A} indicates the number difference of gapless edge modes and gapless edge blind bands.

When the coupling to the environment becomes larger, the blind bands may cross the Fermi surface [Fig.1(c)], i.e., det‚ÄãGA‚Äã(ùê§,œâ=0)=0detsubscriptùê∫ùê¥ùê§ùúî00\text{det}G_{A}(\mathbf{k},\omega=0)=0 for some ùê§ùê§\mathbf{k}, and thus, ChAsubscriptChùê¥\text{Ch}_{A} becomes ill defined even though the energy spectrum is still gapped. For a general gapped system, we propose a topological invariant IAsubscriptùêºùê¥{I}_{A} based on the single-particle density matrix œÅA‚Äã(ùê§)subscriptùúåùê¥ùê§\rho_{A}(\mathbf{k}) with œÅAœÉ‚ÄãœÉ‚Ä≤=‚ü®cA,ùê§‚ÄãœÉ‚Ä≤‚Ä†‚ÄãcA,ùê§‚ÄãœÉ‚ü©superscriptsubscriptùúåùê¥ùúésuperscriptùúé‚Ä≤delimited-‚ü®‚ü©superscriptsubscriptùëêùê¥ùê§superscriptùúé‚Ä≤‚Ä†subscriptùëêùê¥ùê§ùúé\rho_{A}^{\sigma\sigma^{\prime}}=\langle c_{A,\mathbf{k}\sigma^{\prime}}^{\dagger}c_{A,\mathbf{k}\sigma}\rangle, which is equivalent to ChAsubscriptChùê¥\text{Ch}_{A} when the system is weakly coupled to the environment. For a noninteracting system, there is a one-to-one correspondence between the density matrix and the entanglement Hamiltonian‚ÄâPeschel2002 ; Fidkowski2010prl . Unlike the previous discussions of the relation between the entanglement spectrum (entropy) and topological properties of the full system (A+Eùê¥ùê∏A+E)‚ÄâKitaev2006prl ; Hsieh2014prl ; Chandran2014prl , we focus on the physical implication of the eigenstates of the density matrix for Aùê¥A. The index IAsubscriptùêºùê¥{I}_{A} [see Eq.‚Äâ(6) below] is determined by the Berry curvature of the dominant eigenstates of the density matrix œÅA‚Äã(ùê§)subscriptùúåùê¥ùê§\rho_{A}(\mathbf{k}), as proposed in Ref.‚ÄâBudich2015prb for noninteracting systems, giving the number of gapless edge modes for œÅAsubscriptùúåùê¥\rho_{A}.

This paper is organized as follows. In Sec. II, we show that the topological Hamiltonian is applicable for the case when GA‚Äã(ùê§,i‚Äãœâ)subscriptùê∫ùê¥ùê§ùëñùúîG_{A}(\mathbf{k},i\omega) has neither poles nor zeros. In Sec. III, we express the Chern number (1) through the Berry curvature of the bands of the energy spectrum and the blind bands. In Sec. IV, a density-matrix description of topological invariance is developed. In Sec. V, we discuss the applications of our theory.

III Berry curvature method

For the integral (1), considering the contour integral in Fig.‚Äâ1(a) for œâùúî\omega and using the residue theorem, the result depends only on the behavior of the Green‚Äôs function at its poles and zeros (see Appendix A). Generally, the integral (1) gives

Clearly, the value of ChAsubscriptChùê¥\text{Ch}_{A} indicates the difference between the number of gapless edge modes and gapless edge blind bands.

Now, we compare Eq.‚Äâ(3) with the first Chern number of a closed system: the full system. For the full system, the formula of the first Chern number is similar to Eq.‚Äâ(1), but with GAsubscriptùê∫ùê¥G_{A} replaced by GFsubscriptùê∫ùêπG_{F}.

For the full system, the zeros of GF‚Äã(ùê§,œâ)subscriptùê∫ùêπùê§ùúîG_{F}(\mathbf{k},\omega) may appear only for strong interactions with some special symmetries‚ÄâGurarie2011prb , and then the Berry curvature method will give a result similar to that of Eq.‚Äâ(3). In most cases, GF‚Äã(ùê§,œâ)subscriptùê∫ùêπùê§ùúîG_{F}(\mathbf{k},\omega) has no zeros. We suppose that there are, in total, NùëÅN bands for the full system, and the first nùëõn bands are filled. Then the first Chern number of the full system is described by the nùëõn filled (quasiparticle) states,

This provides a method for evaluating the topological index beyond the topological Hamiltonian method.

For an open system Aùê¥A, in general, det‚ÄãGA‚Äã(ùê§,œâ)=0detsubscriptùê∫ùê¥ùê§ùúî0\text{{det}}G_{A}(\mathbf{k},\omega)=0 at some frequencies. To see the emergence of these blind bands, let us for simplicity focus on the noninteracting case. We still suppose that there are in total NùëÅN bands for the full system, and the first nùëõn bands are filled. For the case that the system Aùê¥A decouples from the environment Eùê∏E, we now prove that no blind bands exist. Let the set ‚ÑõA‚â°{|œàj‚Äã(ùê§)‚ü©}j‚ààùí™Asubscript‚Ñõùê¥subscriptketsubscriptùúìùëóùê§ùëósubscriptùí™ùê¥\mathcal{R}_{A}\equiv\{|\psi_{j}(\mathbf{k})\rangle\}_{j\in\mathcal{O}_{A}}, with ùí™A‚â°{1,‚ãØ,m,n+1,‚ãØ,n+m‚Ä≤}subscriptùí™ùê¥1‚ãØùëöùëõ1‚ãØùëõsuperscriptùëö‚Ä≤\mathcal{O}_{A}\equiv\{1,\cdots,m,n+1,\cdots,n+m^{\prime}\} (i.e., mùëöm filled bands and m‚Ä≤superscriptùëö‚Ä≤m^{\prime} unfilled bands) belong to the system Aùê¥A and the other bands ‚ÑõE‚â°{|œàj‚Äã(ùê§)‚ü©}j‚ààùí™Esubscript‚Ñõùê∏subscriptketsubscriptùúìùëóùê§ùëósubscriptùí™ùê∏\mathcal{R}_{E}\equiv\{|\psi_{j}(\mathbf{k})\rangle\}_{j\in\mathcal{O}_{E}}, with ùí™E‚â°{m+1,‚ãØ,n,n+m‚Ä≤+1,‚ãØ,N}subscriptùí™ùê∏ùëö1‚ãØùëõùëõsuperscriptùëö‚Ä≤1‚ãØùëÅ\mathcal{O}_{E}\equiv\{m+1,\cdots,n,n+m^{\prime}+1,\cdots,N\} (i.e., n‚àímùëõùëön-m filled bands and N‚àín‚àím‚Ä≤ùëÅùëõsuperscriptùëö‚Ä≤N-n-m^{\prime} unfilled bands) belong to the environment. So the Green‚Äôs function becomes GA‚Äã(ùê§,œâ)=‚àëj‚ààùí™A|œÜj‚Äã(ùê§)‚ü©‚Äã‚ü®œÜj‚Äã(ùê§)|œâ‚àíŒµj‚Äã(ùê§)subscriptùê∫ùê¥ùê§ùúîsubscriptùëósubscriptùí™ùê¥ketsubscriptùúëùëóùê§brasubscriptùúëùëóùê§ùúîsubscriptùúÄùëóùê§G_{A}(\mathbf{k},\omega)=\sum_{j\in\mathcal{O}_{A}}\frac{|\varphi_{j}(\mathbf{k})\rangle\langle\varphi_{j}(\mathbf{k})|}{\omega-\varepsilon_{j}(\mathbf{k})}. If GA‚Äã(ùê§,œâ)‚Äã|u‚ü©=0subscriptùê∫ùê¥ùê§ùúîketùë¢0G_{A}(\mathbf{k},\omega)|u\rangle=0 for a nonzero |u‚ü©ketùë¢|u\rangle, this implies {|œÜj‚Äã(ùê§)‚ü©}j‚ààùí™Asubscriptketsubscriptùúëùëóùê§ùëósubscriptùí™ùê¥\{|\varphi_{j}(\mathbf{k})\rangle\}_{j\in\mathcal{O}_{A}} are linearly dependent, which contradicts the orthogonality. Therefore, the Green‚Äôs function GAsubscriptùê∫ùê¥G_{A} has no zero eigenvalues.

When the system is weakly coupled to the environment, we have GA‚Äã(ùê§,œâ)=‚àëj=1N|œÜj‚Äã(ùê§)‚ü©‚Äã‚ü®œÜj‚Äã(ùê§)|œâ‚àíŒµj‚Äã(ùê§)subscriptùê∫ùê¥ùê§ùúîsuperscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëÅketsubscriptùúëùëóùê§brasubscriptùúëùëóùê§ùúîsubscriptùúÄùëóùê§G_{A}(\mathbf{k},\omega)=\sum_{j=1}^{N}\frac{|\varphi_{j}(\mathbf{k})\rangle\langle\varphi_{j}(\mathbf{k})|}{\omega-\varepsilon_{j}(\mathbf{k})}, and |œÜj‚Äã(ùê§)‚ü©ketsubscriptùúëùëóùê§|\varphi_{j}(\mathbf{k})\rangle now can be nonzero even for j‚ààùí™Eùëósubscriptùí™ùê∏j\in\mathcal{O}_{E}. Hence, the new poles Œµj‚Äã(ùê§)subscriptùúÄùëóùê§\varepsilon_{j}(\mathbf{k}) from j‚ààùí™Eùëósubscriptùí™ùê∏j\in\mathcal{O}_{E} emerge, accompanied by the appearance of the zeros of GAsubscriptùê∫ùê¥G_{A}‚ÄâGurarie2011prb . The latter cancels the effects from the new bands [see eq.‚Äâ(3)], which is consistent with the robustness of the topological index. Intuitively, the set {|œÜj‚Äã(ùê§)‚ü©}j=1,‚ãØ,Nsubscriptketsubscriptùúëùëóùê§ùëó1‚ãØùëÅ\{|\varphi_{j}(\mathbf{k})\rangle\}_{j=1,\cdots,N} is overcomplete, and it allows |u‚ü©ketùë¢|u\rangle to be an eigenstate of GA‚Äã(ùê§,œâ)subscriptùê∫ùê¥ùê§ùúîG_{A}(\mathbf{k},\omega) with zero eigenvalue. Note that for the new poles ŒµjsubscriptùúÄùëó\varepsilon_{j} with j‚ààùí™Eùëósubscriptùí™ùê∏j\in\mathcal{O}_{E}, one has ùí±j‚â°‚ü®œÜj‚Äã(ùê§)|œÜj‚Äã(ùê§)‚ü©‚â™1subscriptùí±ùëóinner-productsubscriptùúëùëóùê§subscriptùúëùëóùê§much-less-than1\mathcal{V}_{j}\equiv\langle\varphi_{j}(\mathbf{k})|\varphi_{j}(\mathbf{k})\rangle\ll 1 for the weak-coupling case. Thus, for œâùúî\omega away from ŒµjsubscriptùúÄùëó\varepsilon_{j} (j‚ààùí™Eùëósubscriptùí™ùê∏j\in\mathcal{O}_{E}), the weak coupling corrects the Green‚Äôs function slightly and cannot contribute zeros. However, if œâ‚àíŒµj‚àºùí±jsimilar-toùúîsubscriptùúÄùëósubscriptùí±ùëó\omega-\varepsilon_{j}\sim\mathcal{V}_{j} for j‚ààùí™Eùëósubscriptùí™ùê∏j\in\mathcal{O}_{E}, the correction becomes significant. As a result, for the weak-coupling case, the blind bands will always be close to those new bands [Fig.1(b)], and actually, they always appear in pairs‚ÄâGurarie2011prb . Consequently, below the Fermi surface, the number of blind bands and that of the new bands are the same. The number of effective bands occupied in the system Aùê¥A is m‚â°Np‚Äão‚Äãl‚Äãe‚àíNb‚Äãl‚Äãi‚Äãn‚ÄãdùëösubscriptùëÅùëùùëúùëôùëísubscriptùëÅùëèùëôùëñùëõùëëm\equiv N_{pole}-N_{blind}, where Np‚Äão‚Äãl‚ÄãesubscriptùëÅùëùùëúùëôùëíN_{pole} and Nb‚Äãl‚Äãi‚Äãn‚ÄãdsubscriptùëÅùëèùëôùëñùëõùëëN_{blind} are the number of energy bands and blind bands below the Fermi surface, respectively.

IV Density-matrix description

For weak coupling and the noninteracting case, the blind bands are always close to the new poles. This property allows us to smoothly tune Œµj‚Äã(ùê§)subscriptùúÄùëóùê§\varepsilon_{j}(\mathbf{k}) for a well-defined GA‚Äã(ùê§,œâ)subscriptùê∫ùê¥ùê§ùúîG_{A}(\mathbf{k},\omega), avoiding bands or blind bands crossing the zero point, so that the first nùëõn poles [Œµj‚Äã(ùê§)<0subscriptùúÄùëóùê§0\varepsilon_{j}(\mathbf{k})<0] are moved together to ŒµG‚Äã(ùê§)<0subscriptùúÄùê∫ùê§0\varepsilon_{G}(\mathbf{k})<0, and the others are moved to ŒµE‚Äã(ùê§)>0subscriptùúÄùê∏ùê§0\varepsilon_{E}(\mathbf{k})>0, without changing the topological index (1). The final Green‚Äôs function becomes G¬ØA‚Äã(ùê§,œâ)=œÅA‚Äã(ùê§)œâ‚àíŒµG‚Äã(ùê§)+œÅ¬ØA‚Äã(ùê§)œâ‚àíŒµE‚Äã(ùê§)subscript¬Øùê∫ùê¥ùê§ùúîsubscriptùúåùê¥ùê§ùúîsubscriptùúÄùê∫ùê§subscript¬Øùúåùê¥ùê§ùúîsubscriptùúÄùê∏ùê§\underline{G}_{A}(\mathbf{k},\omega)=\frac{\rho_{A}(\mathbf{k})}{\omega-\varepsilon_{G}(\mathbf{k})}+\frac{\overline{\rho}_{A}(\mathbf{k})}{\omega-\varepsilon_{E}(\mathbf{k})}, where œÅA‚Äã(ùê§)=‚àëj=1n|œÜj‚Äã(ùê§)‚ü©‚Äã‚ü®œÜj‚Äã(ùê§)|subscriptùúåùê¥ùê§superscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëõketsubscriptùúëùëóùê§brasubscriptùúëùëóùê§\rho_{A}(\mathbf{k})=\sum_{j=1}^{n}|\varphi_{j}(\mathbf{k})\rangle\langle\varphi_{j}(\mathbf{k})| and œÅ¬ØA‚Äã(ùê§)=‚àëj=n+1N|œÜj‚Äã(ùê§)‚ü©‚Äã‚ü®œÜj‚Äã(ùê§)|subscript¬Øùúåùê¥ùê§superscriptsubscriptùëóùëõ1ùëÅketsubscriptùúëùëóùê§brasubscriptùúëùëóùê§\overline{\rho}_{A}(\mathbf{k})=\sum_{j=n+1}^{N}|\varphi_{j}(\mathbf{k})\rangle\langle\varphi_{j}(\mathbf{k})|. By using the completeness ‚àëj=1N|œàj‚Äã(ùê§)‚ü©‚Äã‚ü®œàj‚Äã(ùê§)|=ùêàsuperscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëÅketsubscriptùúìùëóùê§brasubscriptùúìùëóùê§ùêà\sum_{j=1}^{N}|\psi_{j}(\mathbf{k})\rangle\langle\psi_{j}(\mathbf{k})|=\mathbf{I}, we find œÅ¬ØA=ùêàA‚àíœÅAsubscript¬Øùúåùê¥subscriptùêàùê¥subscriptùúåùê¥\overline{\rho}_{A}=\mathbf{I}_{A}-\rho_{A}, where ùêàAsubscriptùêàùê¥\mathbf{I}_{A} is the unit matrix in the subspace Aùê¥A. In addition, we have œÅAœÉ‚ÄãœÉ‚Ä≤=12‚ÄãœÄ‚Äãi‚Äã‚àÆùëëz‚Äãez‚ÄãœÑ‚ÄãGAœÉ‚ÄãœÉ‚Ä≤‚Äã(ùê§,z)=‚ü®cA,ùê§‚ÄãœÉ‚Ä≤‚Ä†‚ÄãcA,ùê§‚ÄãœÉ‚ü©superscriptsubscriptùúåùê¥ùúésuperscriptùúé‚Ä≤12ùúãùëñcontour-integraldifferential-dùëßsuperscriptùëíùëßùúèsuperscriptsubscriptùê∫ùê¥ùúésuperscriptùúé‚Ä≤ùê§ùëßdelimited-‚ü®‚ü©superscriptsubscriptùëêùê¥ùê§superscriptùúé‚Ä≤‚Ä†subscriptùëêùê¥ùê§ùúé\rho_{A}^{\sigma\sigma^{\prime}}=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\oint dze^{z\tau}G_{A}^{\sigma\sigma^{\prime}}(\mathbf{k},z)=\langle c_{A,\mathbf{k}\sigma^{\prime}}^{\dagger}c_{A,\mathbf{k}\sigma}\rangle.

The topological Hamiltonian for the final Green‚Äôs function G¬ØA‚Äã(ùê§,i‚Äãœâ)subscript¬Øùê∫ùê¥ùê§ùëñùúî\underline{G}_{A}(\mathbf{k},i\omega) is H¬ØAtopo=[ŒµE‚àí1‚ÄãùêàA‚àíx‚ÄãœÅA]‚àí1superscriptsubscript¬Øùêªùê¥toposuperscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptùúÄùê∏1subscriptùêàùê¥ùë•subscriptùúåùê¥1\underline{H}_{A}^{\text{topo}}=[\varepsilon_{E}^{-1}\mathbf{I}_{A}-x\rho_{A}]^{-1}, where x=ŒµE‚àí1‚àíŒµG‚àí1>0ùë•superscriptsubscriptùúÄùê∏1superscriptsubscriptùúÄùê∫10x=\varepsilon_{E}^{-1}-\varepsilon_{G}^{-1}>0. Consequently, the eigenstates of H¬ØAtoposuperscriptsubscript¬Øùêªùê¥topo\underline{H}_{A}^{\text{topo}} with negative eigenvalues are exactly the eigenstates of œÅAsubscriptùúåùê¥\rho_{A} with the largest mùëöm eigenvalues. For the interacting case, using the Lehmann representation of the Green‚Äôs function GAsubscriptùê∫ùê¥G_{A} and by properly tuning the position of the many-body eigenenergy, a similar discussion can be applied and the same conclusion can be obtained (see Appendix D).

For strong coupling, the blind bands may cross the zero point even for a gapped system, in which case the Chern number (1) becomes ill defined. To extend the concept of the topological index to a general gapped system, we propose the following formula as a generalized topological index:

IA=‚àëj=1mŒµŒ±‚ÄãŒ≤2‚ÄãœÄ‚Äãi‚Äã‚à´d2‚Äãk‚Äã‚ü®‚àÇŒ±œà¬Øj‚Äã(ùê§)|‚àÇŒ≤œà¬Øj‚Äã(ùê§)‚ü©,subscriptùêºùê¥superscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëösuperscriptùúÄùõºùõΩ2ùúãùëñsuperscriptùëë2ùëòinner-productsubscriptùõºsubscript¬Øùúìùëóùê§subscriptùõΩsubscript¬Øùúìùëóùê§{I}_{A}=\sum_{j=1}^{m}\frac{\varepsilon^{\alpha\beta}}{2\pi i}\int d^{2}k\langle\partial_{\alpha}\overline{\psi}_{j}(\mathbf{k})|\partial_{\beta}\overline{\psi}_{j}(\mathbf{k})\rangle, (6)

where |œà¬Øj‚Äã(ùê§)‚ü©ketsubscript¬Øùúìùëóùê§|\overline{\psi}_{j}(\mathbf{k})\rangle are the eigenstates of œÅA‚Äã(ùê§)subscriptùúåùê¥ùê§\rho_{A}(\mathbf{k}) with the mùëöm largest eigenvalues. From the above discussion, for the weak-coupling case, we have IA=ChAsubscriptùêºùê¥subscriptChùê¥{I}_{A}=\text{Ch}_{A}. Moreover, formula (6) is the same as the definition of topology for a ‚Äòdensity matrix‚Äô in‚Äâ Bardyn2013njp ; Budich2015prb . For the strong-coupling case with a well-defined ChAsubscriptChA\rm{Ch}_{A}, these two quantities may be different, if the system in this phase region cannot be mapped to an isolated system by smoothly changing (without the blind bands and the energy spectrum crossing the zero point) the parameters such as the coupling strength.

Without interaction and without coupling to the environment, the eigenvalues of œÅAsubscriptùúåùê¥\rho_{A} are 111 (with degeneracy mùëöm) and 00, which gives the gapped flat-band structure. The interaction and coupling will change the single-particle distribution, and the null eigenvalues become finite. However, the mùëöm majority eigenstates are still gapped from the minority eigenstates. The topological phase transition occurs when the mùëömth largest eigenvalue of œÅA‚Äã(ùê§)subscriptùúåùê¥ùê§\rho_{A}(\mathbf{k}) becomes degenerate with the (m+1)ùëö1(m+1)th largest eigenvalue of œÅA‚Äã(ùê§)subscriptùúåùê¥ùê§\rho_{A}(\mathbf{k}) or the gap of the energy spectrum closes (which may lead to an energy band inversion for GAsubscriptùê∫ùê¥G_{A} and thus a sudden change in the eigenstates of œÅAsubscriptùúåùê¥\rho_{A}). In contrast, by the definition of the Chern number (1), the topological phase transition can occur when the blind bands close and reopen a gap between them without any energy band inversion‚ÄâGurarie2011prb .

V Applications

V.1 Z2subscriptùëç2Z_{2} topological invariant

For a time-reversal (ùíØùíØ\mathcal{T})-invariant 2D system, the Z2subscriptùëç2{Z}_{2} topological index in the form of a Green‚Äôs function is a five-dimensional integral‚ÄâWang2010prl . For the case with conserved spin, the Z2subscriptùëç2{Z}_{2} index ŒΩùúà\nu can be expressed through the topological index of the decoupled spin subsystem [see Eq.‚Äâ(1)], i.e., ŒΩ=Ch‚Üë‚Äãmod‚Äã2ùúàsubscriptCh‚Üëmod2\nu=\text{Ch}_{\uparrow}~{}\text{mod}~{}2 Kane2005prl ; Hohenadler2013jpcm ; Wu2006prl ; Xu2006prb , which simplifies the calculation greatly. Here, the Chern number ChœÉsubscriptChùúé\text{Ch}_{\sigma} reflects the number of edge states for each spin. The spin conservation can be violated by different types of spin-orbit coupling (SOC)‚ÄâKane2005prl . In the following, we point out that for the weak SOC case, ŒΩ=Ch‚Üë‚Äãmod‚Äã2ùúàsubscriptCh‚Üëmod2\nu=\text{Ch}_{\uparrow}~{}\text{mod}~{}2, and for a general gapped case, ŒΩ=I‚Üë‚Äãmod‚Äã2ùúàsubscriptùêº‚Üëmod2\nu={I}_{\uparrow}~{}\text{mod}~{}2, relating the topology of the subsystem and that of the full system Prodan2009prb ; Fukui2014jpsj .

Let G‚Üësubscriptùê∫‚ÜëG_{\uparrow} and G‚Üìsubscriptùê∫‚ÜìG_{\downarrow} be the Green‚Äôs functions for each spin subsystem. Due to ùíØùíØ\mathcal{T} symmetry, we have the following relations (see Appendix C): G‚Üë‚àó‚Äã(ùê§,i‚Äãœâ)=G‚Üì‚Äã(‚àíùê§,‚àíi‚Äãœâ)superscriptsubscriptùê∫‚Üëùê§ùëñùúîsubscriptùê∫‚Üìùê§ùëñùúîG_{\uparrow}^{*}(\mathbf{k},i\omega)=G_{\downarrow}(-\mathbf{k},-i\omega), œÅ‚Üë‚àó‚Äã(ùê§)=œÅ‚Üì‚Äã(‚àíùê§)superscriptsubscriptùúå‚Üëùê§subscriptùúå‚Üìùê§\rho_{\uparrow}^{*}(\mathbf{k})=\rho_{\downarrow}(-\mathbf{k}), and G‚Üë‚Äã(ùê§,œâ+i‚ÄãŒ¥)=G‚ÜìT‚Äã(‚àíùê§,œâ+i‚ÄãŒ¥)subscriptùê∫‚Üëùê§ùúîùëñùõøsuperscriptsubscriptùê∫‚Üìùëáùê§ùúîùëñùõøG_{\uparrow}(\mathbf{k},\omega+i\delta)=G_{\downarrow}^{T}(-\mathbf{k},\omega+i\delta). The first two relations imply Ch‚Üë=‚àíCh‚ÜìsubscriptCh‚ÜësubscriptCh‚Üì\text{Ch}_{\uparrow}=-\text{Ch}_{\downarrow} and I‚Üë=‚àíI‚Üìsubscriptùêº‚Üësubscriptùêº‚Üì{I}_{\uparrow}=-{I}_{\downarrow} from Eqs.‚Äâ(1) and‚Äâ(6). The last relation shows a close relation between the density of state for each subsystem, which indicates that the subsystems and the full system close and reopen a gap at the same time. The topological state for the full system is changed when the topological properties in the subsystem are changed due to the SOC coupling to the other subsystem. Thus, the Z2subscriptùëç2Z_{2} index can be obtained from the index IAsubscriptùêºùê¥I_{A} of the subsystem.

In Fig.‚Äâ3 in appendix C, we plot the numerical results for the topological index IAsubscriptùêºùê¥{I}_{A} of the subsystem of the Kane-Mele model, showing the exact relation to the Z2subscriptùëç2{Z}_{2} index, ŒΩ=I‚Üë‚Äãmod‚Äã2ùúàsubscriptùêº‚Üëmod2\nu={I}_{\uparrow}~{}\text{mod}~{}2.

V.2 Proximity effect

A simple but fundamental question is what happens when an ordinary insulator is coupled to a topological insulator. As an example, here we consider a system on a bi-layer honeycomb lattice, with each layer described by the Haldane model‚ÄâHaldane1988prl : HŒ±=[‚àít1‚àë‚ü®i,j‚ü©ci‚ÄãŒ±‚Ä†cj‚ÄãŒ±‚àít2‚àë‚ü®‚ü®i,j‚ü©‚ü©ei‚ÄãŒ∏‚ÄãœïŒ±ci‚ÄãŒ±‚Ä†cj‚ÄãŒ±+H.c.]+mŒ±‚àëi(‚àí1)ici‚ÄãŒ±‚Ä†ci‚ÄãŒ±H_{\alpha}=[-t_{1}\sum_{\langle i,j\rangle}c_{i\alpha}^{\dagger}c_{j\alpha}-t_{2}\sum_{\langle\langle i,j\rangle\rangle}e^{i\theta\phi_{\alpha}}c_{i\alpha}^{\dagger}c_{j\alpha}+{\rm H.c.}]+m_{\alpha}\sum_{i}(-1)^{i}c_{i\alpha}^{\dagger}c_{i\alpha}, where t1subscriptùë°1t_{1} is the nearest-neighbor tunneling, t2subscriptùë°2t_{2} is the next-nearest-neighbor tunneling with a phase Œ∏‚ÄãœïŒ±ùúÉsubscriptitalic-œïùõº\theta\phi_{\alpha} and Œ∏=¬±1ùúÉplus-or-minus1\theta=\pm 1, mŒ±subscriptùëöùõºm_{\alpha} is the staggered potential, and Œ±=1,2ùõº12\alpha=1,2 is the layer index. The parameters are t1=4‚Äãt2subscriptùë°14subscriptùë°2t_{1}=4t_{2}, œï1=œÄ/2subscriptitalic-œï1ùúã2\phi_{1}=\pi/2, m1=0subscriptùëö10m_{1}=0, œï2=0subscriptitalic-œï20\phi_{2}=0, and m2=0.2‚Äãt2subscriptùëö20.2subscriptùë°2m_{2}=0.2t_{2}, so that the first layer is a Chern insulator, and the second one is an ordinary insulator.

To observe the interference effect, we further introduce a tunneling term between layers, H12=t12‚Äã‚àëici‚Äã2‚Ä†‚Äãci‚Äã1+H.cformulae-sequencesubscriptùêª12subscriptùë°12subscriptùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëêùëñ2‚Ä†subscriptùëêùëñ1HcH_{12}=t_{12}\sum_{i}c_{i2}^{\dagger}c_{i1}+\rm{H.c}. The topological index IAsubscriptIùê¥\text{I}_{A} with respect to the tunneling coefficient t12subscriptùë°12t_{12} is shown in Fig.‚Äâ2a. In the whole region of t12/t2subscriptùë°12subscriptùë°2t_{12}/t_{2}, the index IAsubscriptùêºùê¥I_{A} for the first layer is unchanged. For the second layer, there are no edge modes or edge blind bands when t12=0subscriptùë°120t_{12}=0. For a small finite t12subscriptùë°12t_{12}, since the full system has gapless poles on the edge, the second layer also has a gapless edge state and simultaneously a gapless blind state appear. The Chern number ChA=IAsubscriptChùê¥subscriptùêºùê¥\text{Ch}_{A}={I}_{A} is still zero, like as the new bulk-boundary correspondence we claimed. The second layer subsystem obtains a nonzero topological index when t12‚â≥0.83‚Äãt2greater-than-or-equivalent-tosubscriptùë°120.83subscriptùë°2t_{12}\gtrsim 0.83t_{2}, while the full system displays a transition from a Chern insulator to a trivial one through band inversion. For t12‚â≥0.83‚Äãt2greater-than-or-equivalent-tosubscriptùë°120.83subscriptùë°2t_{12}\gtrsim 0.83t_{2}, the stable edge state disappears, but the gapless blind band remains, and thus, IA=‚àí1subscriptùêºùê¥1I_{A}=-1 for the second layer. For t12=2.5‚Äãt2subscriptùë°122.5subscriptùë°2t_{12}=2.5t_{2}, the spectrum of the full system with zigzag edges is shown in Fig.‚Äâ2(b), which has no edge states. However, the spectrum of the density matrix for each layer contains a gapless edge state, which is shown in Fig.‚Äâ2(c). For the second layer, the blind bands become gapless at the edge [Fig.‚Äâ2(d)].

VI Conclusion

We have systemically discussed the topology of 2D open systems. The invariant given by the Ishikawa-Matsuyama formula reflects the number difference of gapless edge modes and gapless edge blind bands. Moreover, we defined another topological invariant in terms of the single-particle density matrix which is applicable for general gapped systems and is equivalent to the former invariant for the case of weak coupling to the environment. Two applications were discussed. For time-reversal invariant insulators, we explained that the relation of the Chern invariant for each spin subsystem and the Z2subscriptùëç2{Z}_{2} index of the full system is given by ŒΩ=I‚Üë‚Äãmod‚Äã2ùúàsubscriptùêº‚Üëmod2\nu={I}_{\uparrow}~{}\text{mod}~{}2, which highly simplifies the calculation for the Z2subscriptùëç2{Z}_{2} index. In addition, we consider the proximity effect when an ordinary insulator is coupled to a topological insulator, which shows an inverse topological invariant is induced by the nontrivial part Hsieh2016prl .

The examples given here are for non-interacting cases. The method can be applied to the interacting system, also at finite temperature, and the single-particle density matrix can be obtained, for example, by using dynamical mean-field theory.

For the interacting case, |œà1‚Äã(ùê§)‚ü©,|œà2‚Äã(ùê§)‚ü©,‚ãØ,|œàn‚Äã(ùê§)‚ü©ketsubscriptùúì1ùê§ketsubscriptùúì2ùê§‚ãØketsubscriptùúìùëõùê§|\psi_{1}(\mathbf{k})\rangle,|\psi_{2}(\mathbf{k})\rangle,\cdots,|\psi_{n}(\mathbf{k})\rangle are not orthogonal to each other. In the following, we prove that these states can be smoothly deformed to an orthogonal basis without changing ChFsubscriptChùêπ\text{Ch}_{F}, supposing that they are still linear independent. Using Gram-Schmidt orthogonalization, we define an orthogonal orthogonal basis: |Œ®1‚Äã(ùê§)‚ü©=|œà1‚Äã(ùê§)‚ü©ketsubscriptŒ®1ùê§ketsubscriptùúì1ùê§|\Psi_{1}(\mathbf{k})\rangle=|\psi_{1}(\mathbf{k})\rangle, |Œ®2‚Äã(ùê§)‚ü©=|œà2‚Äã(ùê§)‚ü©‚àí‚ü®Œ®1‚Äã(ùê§)|œà2‚Äã(ùê§)‚ü©‚Äã|Œ®1‚Äã(ùê§)‚ü©‚Äñ|œà2‚Äã(ùê§)‚ü©‚àí‚ü®Œ®1‚Äã(ùê§)|œà2‚Äã(ùê§)‚ü©‚Äã|Œ®1‚Äã(ùê§)‚ü©‚ÄñketsubscriptŒ®2ùê§ketsubscriptùúì2ùê§inner-productsubscriptŒ®1ùê§subscriptùúì2ùê§ketsubscriptŒ®1ùê§normketsubscriptùúì2ùê§inner-productsubscriptŒ®1ùê§subscriptùúì2ùê§ketsubscriptŒ®1ùê§|\Psi_{2}(\mathbf{k})\rangle=\frac{|\psi_{2}(\mathbf{k})\rangle-\langle\Psi_{1}(\mathbf{k})|\psi_{2}(\mathbf{k})\rangle|\Psi_{1}(\mathbf{k})\rangle}{|||\psi_{2}(\mathbf{k})\rangle-\langle\Psi_{1}(\mathbf{k})|\psi_{2}(\mathbf{k})\rangle|\Psi_{1}(\mathbf{k})\rangle||}, ‚ãØ‚ãØ\cdots. It is easy to check that ‚ü®Œ®j‚Äã(ùê§)|œàj‚Äã(ùê§)‚ü©=‚ü®œàj‚Äã(ùê§)|Œ®j‚Äã(ùê§)‚ü©>0inner-productsubscriptŒ®ùëóùê§subscriptùúìùëóùê§inner-productsubscriptùúìùëóùê§subscriptŒ®ùëóùê§0\langle\Psi_{j}(\mathbf{k})|\psi_{j}(\mathbf{k})\rangle=\langle\psi_{j}(\mathbf{k})|\Psi_{j}(\mathbf{k})\rangle>0 for j=1,‚ãØ,nùëó1‚ãØùëõj=1,\cdots,n. The smooth deformation then is defined by (t‚àà[0,1]ùë°01t\in[0,1])

|Œ®i‚Äã(ùê§,t)‚ü©=(1‚àít)‚Äã|œài‚Äã(ùê§)‚ü©+t‚Äã|Œ®i‚Äã(ùê§)‚ü©‚Äñ(1‚àít)‚Äã|œài‚Äã(ùê§)‚ü©+t‚Äã|Œ®i‚Äã(ùê§)‚ü©‚Äñ.ketsubscriptŒ®ùëñùê§ùë°1ùë°ketsubscriptùúìùëñùê§ùë°ketsubscriptŒ®ùëñùê§norm1ùë°ketsubscriptùúìùëñùê§ùë°ketsubscriptŒ®ùëñùê§|\Psi_{i}(\mathbf{k},t)\rangle=\frac{(1-t)|\psi_{i}(\mathbf{k})\rangle+t|\Psi_{i}(\mathbf{k})\rangle}{||(1-t)|\psi_{i}(\mathbf{k})\rangle+t|\Psi_{i}(\mathbf{k})\rangle||}. (22)

This deformation is well defined since ‚Äñ(1‚àít)‚Äã|œài‚Äã(ùê§)‚ü©+t‚Äã|Œ®i‚Äã(ùê§)‚ü©‚Äñ=(1‚àít)2+t2+(1‚àít)‚Äãt‚Äã[‚ü®œài‚Äã(ùê§)|Œ®i‚Äã(ùê§)‚ü©+‚ü®Œ®i‚Äã(ùê§)|œài‚Äã(ùê§)‚ü©]>0norm1ùë°ketsubscriptùúìùëñùê§ùë°ketsubscriptŒ®ùëñùê§superscript1ùë°2superscriptùë°21ùë°ùë°delimited-[]inner-productsubscriptùúìùëñùê§subscriptŒ®ùëñùê§inner-productsubscriptŒ®ùëñùê§subscriptùúìùëñùê§0||(1-t)|\psi_{i}(\mathbf{k})\rangle+t|\Psi_{i}(\mathbf{k})\rangle||=(1-t)^{2}+t^{2}+(1-t)t[\langle\psi_{i}(\mathbf{k})|\Psi_{i}(\mathbf{k})\rangle+\langle\Psi_{i}(\mathbf{k})|\psi_{i}(\mathbf{k})\rangle]>0. Thus, we have defined a smooth deformation, so that |œà1‚Äã(ùê§)‚ü©ketsubscriptùúì1ùê§|\psi_{1}(\mathbf{k})\rangle, |œà2‚Äã(ùê§)‚ü©ketsubscriptùúì2ùê§|\psi_{2}(\mathbf{k})\rangle, ‚ãØ‚ãØ\cdots, |œàn‚Äã(ùê§)‚ü©ketsubscriptùúìùëõùê§|\psi_{n}(\mathbf{k})\rangle go to |Œ®1‚Äã(ùê§)‚ü©ketsubscriptŒ®1ùê§|\Psi_{1}(\mathbf{k})\rangle, |Œ®2‚Äã(ùê§)‚ü©ketsubscriptŒ®2ùê§|\Psi_{2}(\mathbf{k})\rangle, ‚ãØ‚ãØ\cdots, |Œ®n‚Äã(ùê§)‚ü©ketsubscriptŒ®ùëõùê§|\Psi_{n}(\mathbf{k})\rangle without changing the Chern number. And using the U‚Äã(n)ùëàùëõU(n) symmetry of the Chern number for the orthogonal basis, we get the conclusion that the Chern number is related only to the space spanned by |œà1‚Äã(ùê§)‚ü©,|œà2‚Äã(ùê§)‚ü©,‚ãØ,|œàn‚Äã(ùê§)‚ü©ketsubscriptùúì1ùê§ketsubscriptùúì2ùê§‚ãØketsubscriptùúìùëõùê§|\psi_{1}(\mathbf{k})\rangle,|\psi_{2}(\mathbf{k})\rangle,\cdots,|\psi_{n}(\mathbf{k})\rangle.

Appendix C Time-reversal-invariant system
